My kids are looking for colleges, so I made a site with college info that others might like: https://collegetables.info/. Includes info like faculty and student demographics over time, finances over time, abortion access in the state, state rep support for same-sex marriage, what fields students graduate in, etc.

It's open source (https://github.com/bomeara/collegetables) and uses #rstats and #rmarkdown

Please let me know what other sources of data would be helpful!

#college #highered #ipeds

We're looking for help to build a wireless, solar-powered chat network across the Philly area! Are you interested in learning about off-grid solar power? Do you have a sunny place on your roof, in your yard, or near an upstairs window where you can leave a small radio transceiver? This workshop may be for you!

Each participant will receive a free kit with all the parts needed to build a solar-powered LoRa radio node. You'll assemble the kit, mount it in a weatherproof enclosure (provided by you), and use the Meshtastic app to start sending encrypted text messages.

Registration opens Monday, April 3rd at 8:30 p.m. You can sign up on our site:
https://iffybooks.net/event/solar-chat-network

Supplies for this workshop are provided by a grant from the Engaged Humanities Studio at Swarthmore College. Many thanks to @pixouls for helping plan the event!

title: Orion Magazine - Geography as Generosity: An Afternoon with Barry Lopez

last_post.content:
"Good place-language, well used, opens onto mystery, grows knowledge, and summons wonder. And in the absence of an exact and detail-giving lexis, the living world can blur into a generalized wash of green, becoming an easily disposable backdrop. Certainly, the nuances observed by specialized vocabularies of place-perception are evaporating from common usage, burnt off by capital, apathy, and virtualization.

https://orionmagazine.org/article/barry-lopez-from-here-to-the-horizon/

Research Article
Knitted origami
Elizabeth L. Wilmer

"Techniques are presented for embedding horizontal, vertical, and45◦diagonal crease lines into garter stitch knitted fabric. While theseare mostly based on standard lace knitting stitches, the horizon-tal creases use double-cable-crossed elongated stitches in a non-standard way. This crease library suffices to knit a model of a squaretwist, a foundational origami tessellation unit."

https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/epdf/10.1080/17513472.2023.2191572

With contributions from the whole team, of course, i.a. @MariaHinzmann, @naudgnit, Julia Röttgermann, Anne Klee, Moritz Steffes. – https://scai.sorbonne-universite.fr/public/events/view/36309bbdc8d06c255798 – Slides are ready! https://mimotext.github.io/lod-lithist/fra.html#/

#SCAI event in #Paris: I give a talk on 4 April 2023 at the #ObTIC Seminar at the #Sorbonne, hosted by Glenn Roe: "Pour une histoire littéraire ouverte et en réseau: le projet Mining and Modeling Text". With contributions from the whole team, of course, i.a. @MariaHinzmann, @naudgnit, Julia Röttgermann, Anne Klee, Moritz Steffes. – https://scai.sorbonne-universite.fr/public/events/view/36309bbdc8d06c255798 – Slides are ready! https://mimotext.github.io/lod-lithist/fra.html#/

We are now launching our search for the next IntroComp organizer!

Details on how to express interest and the anticipated next steps are posted on http://introcomp.org.

The deadline for expressing your interest in being considered is Wednesday, April 19, 2023.

last_post.content:

title: ~this week in security~ | creating a free weekly cybersecurity newsletter | Patreon

last_post.content:
~this week in security~ goes out to about 12,000 weekly subscribers (with no tracking!). It costs me hundreds of dollars a month to send out. As a working journalist, I don't accept ads or sponsors for my weekly newsletter, so donations from readers help to keep the costs down.

Please consider supporting! https://www.patreon.com/thisweekinsecurity

title: Python Plotting With Matplotlib (Guide) – Real Python

last_post.content:
This is a great intro to how matplotlib works under the hood: https://realpython.com/python-matplotlib-guide/

If you're a beginner like me, you're mindlessly copy/pasting from examples and remaining confused about the difference between figures and axes, thinking that the whole thing is object oriented (after all, it's python...) and therefore plt.plot() must be a method for the plt object (it's NOT!), why the heck we call plt.subplots() when there is only a single plot, etc. Prepare to be enlightened!

#matplotlib

R.I.P. Ryuichi Sakamoto, a Japanese musical legend, an activist, my inspiration.

The news of his departure was on the cover page of today’s newspaper.

He was probably the most internationally successful Japanese musician of all time, and he won an Oscar, a BAFTA, a Grammy, and 2 Golden Globe Awards (https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryuichi_Sakamoto).

Here are some thought about the #Twitter #recsys algorithm. Not focusing on the stack. I think anyone with industry experience really does not care if it is scala, tensorflow, pytorch. A tool is a tool.
1. I was surprised by the simplicity of https://github.com/twitter/the-algorithm-ml/blob/main/projects/twhin/models/models.py. at the same time it is interesting to see they use sgd with 2 different lr. So clearly it is not an MVP.
2. Multitask learning for the ranking is great. The actual aggregation of the loss still is relatively naive but it does it.
